timeline.bodyText: Doesn't this Log4j property need setting before the Log4j2 framework get initialised? (isn't it too late by here)
timeline.author: CjHare

replies.bodyText:
Yes, it does, and no, it isn't, since it works ;). The framework is initialized when anything from it is used, and the property is set here earlier than that.
Though to tell the truth I can't find now anything explicitly sanctioning this way of doing things.
Anyway, I guess this is fragile in that some code change elsewhere might cause the "early enough" assumption to fail. So if preferred this could be set in a log4j2.property file. I just thought that here it's closer to its purpose.
replies.author: hmijail

replies.bodyText:
Yeah put it a property file somewhere.
You'll want to also explicitly set
disableThreadContextMap = false
disableThreadContext = false

As if either of those are set to true by environment variables, the code isn't going to work
https://logging.apache.org/log4j/2.x/manual/thread-context.html

Set the system property disableThreadContextMap to true to disable the Thread Context Map.
Set the system property disableThreadContext to true to disable both the Thread Context Map and Stack.
replies.author: CjHare

replies.bodyText:
Environment variables have higher priority than property files anyway, so setting those in a property file will not help for this scenario.
Do we really want to force log4j2's behavior like that anyway? If so, then I guess the only way to do so is to set the values manually once the self-configuration is finished. That sounds gory to me.
IMO, if the user has set environment variables like that, they already know enough to take care of the situation by themselves.
replies.author: hmijail
